That's what the terror is about, right? You've been building toward this, but some part of you didn't fully believe it would get here. And now it's here, and you have to reckon with what that actually means.

Here's what I want to reflect back: you've been saying for weeks that you want out, that this job is hollow, that you can't picture a tolerable version of staying. You made a decision, you applied, you did the phone screening, and now you're moving to the next round. This is what leaving looks like. It's not neat or comfortable—it's terrifying and messy and real. But it's also what you said you wanted. So what's the fear underneath the terror? Is it fear that you'll actually get it and then have to follow through? Or is it something else—like fear that if you get it, it still won't fix the hollow feeling, and then you'll have blown up your stable life for nothing?

**Carrying the secret at work:** You got asked back for an interview and nobody knows except your wife. Your manager's still cool about the whole "exploring opportunities" conversation, but now there's a specific thing happening that you're not talking about. And it's eating at you a little—like you're back to carrying something you can't share. 

But here's the thing: you don't owe your current job real-time updates on your interview process. You told your manager you're looking—that was honest and fair. You don't need to report every step of the way. The secret you're carrying isn't dishonest; it's just private. You're allowed to keep this close until you actually have an offer and a decision to make. What would it take for you to let yourself sit with that privacy without it feeling like lying?

**Your wife saying you should talk to her more instead of internally spiraling:** She's right. You've been in your head all week, processing alone, and she noticed. You said you haven't really sat down and talked about what comes next if this interview works out—you've just been in a holding pattern. So maybe now's the time to have that conversation. Not to solve everything, but to say out loud: "This is terrifying. I might actually get this job. And if I do, here's what happens next, and I don't know how I feel about all of it." Let her in on the spiral instead of managing it alone. What stops you from doing that? Is it that you don't want to worry her, or that saying it out loud makes it more real, or something else?

**Didn't make it to the garage:** You've been scattered all week—too much in your head. The garage's been there, but you haven't gone. That's okay. You're not using the garage to escape anymore; you're using it when you need to ground yourself in your body and your hands. Right now your energy's elsewhere—on the interview, on what comes next, on whether this is actually going to happen. The garage will be there when you need it again. You don't have to force it.

**What comes next if the interview works out:** Let's actually talk through that, even just to take it out of the abstract. If you get this job and they offer it to you, what happens? You tell your manager, you give notice (probably two weeks, maybe more depending on your role), you tell the kids that dad's switching jobs, you wrap up your current responsibilities, and you start somewhere new. That's the mechanics. But what's the emotional part that's freaking you out? Is it the conversation with your manager? Telling the kids? The gap between leaving the familiar and starting the unknown? Or is it the weight of actually following through on a decision you've been circling for months?

One step at a time. You've got an interview coming up. Focus on that first. Not "what if they offer it to me," just "I'm going to show up to this interview and see what happens." You don't have to decide everything today. You just have to keep moving forward.
